summary: This is a Bloomberg newsletter from October 30, 2019, covering various financial and news topics. It includes a brief report on the disputed findings regarding Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy, where a forensic pathologist hired by Epstein's brother stated the evidence pointed more toward homicide than suicide, contradicting the official ruling.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of an autopsy report discussed in the newsletter. A forensic pathologist hired by his brother disputed the official suicide ruling, suggesting evidence was more consistent with homicide.

persons.name: Michael Baden
persons.role: Forensic pathologist, former New York City medical examiner
persons.context: Hired by Jeffrey Epstein's brother to review the autopsy. He stated on Fox & Friends that the findings were more consistent with strangulation/homicide than suicide, citing fractures in the hyoid bone.

persons.name: Jerome Powell
persons.context: Quoted in the newsletter regarding the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision and monetary policy stance.

persons.name: Tim Cook
persons.context: Quoted expressing optimism about Apple's holiday quarter sales.

persons.name: Jack Dorsey
persons.context: Announced via tweet that Twitter would ban political advertising.

persons.name: Kamala Harris
persons.context: Mentioned as a candidate whose campaign is cutting staff and slashing pay due to financial pressures and dropping poll numbers.

persons.name: Juan Rodriguez
persons.context: Outlined campaign restructuring in a memo, citing a competitive resources environment.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to the canceled APEC summit and plans to attend a mixed martial arts bout in New York.

persons.name: Xi Jinping
persons.context: Mentioned as expected to sign a preliminary trade deal with Donald Trump at the canceled APEC summit.

persons.name: Sebastian Pinera
persons.context: Announced the cancellation of the APEC summit and COP25 conference in Santiago due to protests.

persons.name: Susan Desmond-Hellmann
persons.context: Mentioned as stepping down from Facebook's board.

persons.name: Jorge Masvidal
persons.context: Mentioned as headlining an MMA bout at Madison Square Garden that President Trump planned to attend.

persons.name: Nate Diaz
persons.context: Mentioned as headlining an MMA bout at Madison Square Garden that President Trump planned to attend.

connections.description: Michael Baden was hired by Jeffrey Epstein's brother to review and provide an expert opinion on Epstein's autopsy findings.

events.title: Bloomberg newsletter reports on Epstein autopsy dispute
events.description: A Bloomberg newsletter includes a report that forensic pathologist Dr. Michael Baden, hired by Epstein's brother, stated Epstein's autopsy findings were more consistent with homicide by strangulation than suicide, contradicting the official ruling.

events.title: Federal Reserve interest rate cut
events.description: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the third time in 2019 but signaled a pause in further easing.

events.title: Chile cancels APEC and COP25 summits
events.description: Chilean President Sebastian Pinera canceled the APEC summit (where a U.S.-China trade deal was expected) and the COP25 climate conference due to ongoing deadly protests.

locations: Madison Square Garden, New York City
keyFacts: A forensic pathologist, Dr. Michael Baden, hired by Jeffrey Epstein's brother, publicly disputed the official suicide ruling, stating the autopsy was 'more consistent with strangulation than suicide' and that evidence pointed toward homicide.
The dispute over Epstein's cause of death was reported in a mainstream financial news newsletter, indicating the story's broad reach beyond tabloid or niche reporting.
The official cause of death, as stated by the New York City chief medical examiner, was suicide by hanging, which Baden's analysis contradicted.
Baden specifically cited fractures in the hyoid bone as being 'very unusual for suicide' as part of his evidence for potential homicide.
